title: One thing that didn't make sense in Veigar's patch notes
body:
You guys stated that you could either tackle his damage or utility, so go for the latter because you don't want a burst mage to 100-20 instead of 100-0.
So you nerf his E.

But then also his R's damage? What's the explanation behind this?

replies.body: Veigar is supposedly able to obtain more AP throughout the match with his new Q, which was the justification for nerfing the AP ratio. That's what they stated.

> [{quoted}](name=Rivini,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=olh9V4nU,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2015-03-01T10:29:37.986+0000)
>
> Veigar is supposedly able to obtain more AP throughout the match with his new Q, which was the justification for nerfing the AP ratio. That's what they stated.

More ap doesn't untrashify him. 

There's two points to this. One, riot specifically said they weren't reducing his damage.

Two, people need to stop thinking that having more AP means that you're winning. Having more AP from q in most cases means you afk farmed in your lane which will almost certainly fuck your team over because you have no presence on the map.

> [{quoted}](name=Sadistic Veigar,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=olh9V4nU,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2015-03-01T10:35:43.019+0000)
>
> More ap doesn't untrashify him. 
> 
> There's two points to this. One, riot specifically said they weren't reducing his damage.
> 
> Two, people need to stop thinking that having more AP means that you're winning. Having more AP from q in most cases means you afk farmed in your lane which will almost certainly fuck your team over because you have no presence on the map.

Technically speaking, his overall damage wasn't lessened bearing in mind the Q change. That's what they were going for.

So your logic is the mid laner needs to be a roamer to win the match... then why pick Veigar? There are plenty of mid lane picks who are better at roaming, mainly due to their mobility which includes jumping over walls (Zed, Katarina, LeBlanc, etc.). 

While Riot continues to cater to the mobility creep in order to keep the LCS exciting to watch, old fashioned mages like Veigar are just out of place now. Also because of how much he excels at stopping mobility with his stun (like Kalista's hopping) and him lacking much of a "play-making" kit, Riot doesn't want that to continue so they are slowly taking him out of the picture through nerfs. Remember that he was picked a couple times as a support (plus one time mid) and would likely be a replacement for Annie (FIRE AND GIANT TEDDY BEAR OHMAHGAWD!) if Riot didn't intervene.
Why do you think Nasus got nerfed after he was picked a few times in the LCS? He makes top lane a bore fest. He's not jumping around the map or consistently making flashy effects happen. All he does is Q minions. That's not exciting LCS material, so they made sure the pros won't want to pick him anymore. The same thing is happening with Veigar and will happen with more "boring" champions. As soon as Malzahar gets picked in the LCS, he'll receive a beating from the nerf bat too, along with Brand, Garen, Gangplank, and so on.

The LCS is all that matters now, and if a champion isn't "LCS viable" and tries to get into the spotlight, there is little to no hesitation in swinging the nerf bat at them. 
Case in point: Zed, Lee Sin and Thresh. Look at how they "balance" them. Then look at Veigar, Nasus and Sona.

Thresh hasn't got a buff in a long time; if i'm not mistaken the last 3 patches to him or so where nerfs. So you statements is half true. Then other immobile champions are gotten buffs (Annie to be precise) and besides a flash+tibbers she has no real flashy moves. 

If anything, most of veigar damage is still intact, and you seem to forget Event Horizon was meant as a defensive tool to keep enemies away from veigar and that is still possible if you place it closer to you. It's true that most of the offensive capabilities of event horizon is gone but you have to remember it wasn't intended to be used offensively. I don't main veigar and to be honest I haven't played him much recently other than in ARAM but i believe focusing on CDR now would result beneficial on veigar now as some sort of mid range mage dealing constant (high damage) every 4 sec or so.

> [{quoted}](name=RogueWill,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=olh9V4nU,comment-id=0000000000000001,timestamp=2015-03-01T22:45:59.630+0000)
>
> Thresh hasn't got a buff in a long time; if i'm not mistaken the last 3 patches to him or so where nerfs. So you statements is half true. Then other immobile champions are gotten buffs (Annie to be precise) and besides a flash+tibbers she has no real flashy moves. 

Thresh was broken on release and is still broken to this day. The fact that literally every ability in his kit makes exciting plays happen keeps him safe from proper balancing. Compare him to Sona and Janna's balance histories.

The nerfs Thresh gets? 

-Lost 25 range on his basic attacks. 
*WHOOPTY-DO!* Thresh can be **melee** and still be a top tier support. His attack range is irrelevant to the utility he brings.

-Lantern shields only himself and one ally. 
That's fine for ARAM, but bot lane on SR consists of 2 people. Therefore, the nerf has no meaningful effect and still retains the main reason for using the lantern.

Thresh will never be balanced as long as he remains a major play-maker to make those exciting LCS plays happen. I guarantee you he would be gutted if there was no LCS. 

This same principle applies to Zed. No one argued his attack speed was the reason he's too strong, but that's where Riot focused on him just so a nerf could be applied and give us the illusion that they care about what we think, all the while keeping him attractive to the pros so he still gets picked in the LCS. They want us to see the nerf and go "Yay! Finally a nerf! Riot does care!" In reality, we're not that naÃ¯ve. 

Now we've come to Veigar, the yordle who excels at putting mobility creep to a halt. Especially when you consider Veigar can stop Kalista from hopping around by just having the cage surrounding her, Riot didn't want a champion who can effortlessly prevent #LC$bigplays, hence the delay on the stun. Veigar has had that stun since he was released, but Kalista whined to Riot about it so they suddenly jumped on the change.

Annie is full of fiery effects, not just from Tibbers. The ability to control a giant teddy bear is intriguing to people watching, especially those who may consider giving the game a try (the target audience). She received buffs because Janna was beginning to make a return, but of course just buffing an "LCS viable" champion sometimes isn't enough. Why else do you think Janna quickly got nerfed once again, harshly at that?

May I remind you annie buff were mid based? When was the last time yous saw an Annie mid on LCS? If Veigar was so good at stopping LCS plays why wasn;t he picked on LCS to begin with? and Janna is one champion that can make really flashy plays with her kit, she is definitely LCS material why would nerf her under your reasoning?

> [{quoted}](name=RogueWill,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=olh9V4nU,comment-id=000000000000000100020000,timestamp=2015-03-02T01:07:24.664+0000)
>
> May I remind you annie buff were mid based? When was the last time yous saw an Annie mid on LCS? If Veigar was so good at stopping LCS plays why wasn;t he picked on LCS to begin with? and Janna is one champion that can make really flashy plays with her kit, she is definitely LCS material why would nerf her under your reasoning?

How was it mid-based? Are you saying a faster and tankier Tibbers doesn't make support Annie better? If anything, the nerf to her E (on herself) hurts mid Annie more than support.
The purpose of Tibbers is to stun an enemy team (with burst damage) at range, apply additional damage over time, and tank objectives. It doesn't matter whether Annie is playing support or mid, aside from damage output. If Tibbers can do those 3 things, he's doing his job.

Veigar didn't see much LCS play because his stun is his only selling point at that elo range and it isn't a guaranteed stun to begin with. His stun isn't targeted like Annie's Q and can't easily stun a team like Tibbers or even Annie's W, nor does he have a pet to tank objectives with. A competent team that works together can handle Veigar and will get MR to counter his burst.

Janna doesn't have a lot of flashiness in her kit. She has the tornado and her high cooldown ult that can *sometimes* make plays if used at the right moment. That's it. Her W doesn't look much different from her basic attack and her shield is rather plain.
Annie, on the other hand, emits pretty fiery effects on all of her abilities and controls a giant, flaming teddy bear. Additionally, being a little girl shows greater diversity in the League roster. It's certainly more welcoming to see than yet another half-naked woman who talks like a slut.
All of Thresh's abilities are easy to see and understand from an inexperienced person's perspective (and look presentable on top of it), plus as already stated, every single one of them makes plays happen, not just one normal ability and an ult only if used correctly.

> [{quoted}](name=Rivini,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=olh9V4nU,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2015-03-01T10:29:37.986+0000)

> Veigar is supposedly able to obtain more AP throughout the match with his new Q, which was the justification for nerfing the AP ratio. That's what they stated.

That's like giving Nasus's Q 5 stacks per minion, but giving his Q a 60% chance to hit.

I have a question! How does his AP build up faster? I haven't seen the details, but assuming the reasoning is because he can kill 2 minions at once instead of just 1, how exactly does that matter? I mean minion waves won't spawn faster just because you are killing more at once.

It's more significant earlier because it has reduced rank 1 cooldown as well, and there's no way you could last hit every minion with Q for most of the game so being able to get two from one Q would double it with the same cooldown until you get to the point where he COULD previously last hit every minion with Q... by which point he should be blowing people up instead of AFK farming anyway.

Also, at least in theory, the new Q can get a stack AND harass the enemy laner at the same time, especially with the increased range. That may not be the most common of situations (and it can lead to pushing the lane unintentionally, which Veigar hates because he can't escape a gank at all) but I am told old Veigar did frequently use Q for harass instead of farming so now he's at least sometimes getting stacks from that.

I think someone did the math and, assuming Veigar hits his W somehow, his damage is still well below old DFG burst, but significantly higher than old Veigar with the same build if he gets two minions with Q every now and then. The problem is the "Hits his W somehow" since that's pretty much impossible without landing a stun, and landing a stun is pretty much impossible.

Not saying it was a good change, but I think if they decide that champions should be viable and they improve his stun or think of a better alternative than gutting it then he should still be able to burst people about as well.

> [{quoted}](name=kDrakari,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=olh9V4nU,comment-id=00040000,timestamp=2015-03-01T14:36:09.519+0000)

I've been running flat CDR blues and quints which, when combined with the 5% CDR mastery, gave me a starting CDR of 20%, I could totally last-hit every minion from level 3 and on(2nd rank in Q). This lead to me having more gold and AP by the mid-game and helping me to secure enough of an advantage that I could start offing enemy champs with relative ease(if they weren't cautious).

> I've been running flat CDR blues and quints which, when combined with the 5% CDR mastery, gave me a starting CDR of 20%, I could totally last-hit every minion from level 3 and on(2nd rank in Q

How did you have the mana pool to sustain that though?

EDIT: Just looked up his stats; he has roughly 340 mana lvl 1, and his lvl 1 Q costs 60 mana. Taking into account regen, masteries, and his passive, and assuming you're right in that 20% CDR allows you to last hit every single minion, you'd basically go oom after one wave, maybe be able to squeeze in an extra minion or two, since you're talking about his lvl 3 (which I don't think the math changes much, especially since his Q mana cost increases as well)

EDIT2: I forgot to mention the regen from Doran's or if you opt into taking flask or something, but I think the overall problem still remains
Flask and mana potions(one or 2) + his innate. I had mana problems for sure though.

You don't get to Q every minion. Mana and time constraints prevent it. Would I really spend 20ish seconds last hitting every single minion in a wave with Q when I could be doing something else useful like roaming or fighting opponents. I'd often W a wave to clear it and only last hit 1-2 minions with Q because I just didn't have time. Now, I can get more Q last hits in the same period of time. The AP absolutely builds up faster. It's not enough to make up for the major nerfs to his kit, but you should have more AP with new Veigar than with the old one.

So the theory is this:

1. Old Veigar would either have to use his Q to harass the enemy (according to a lot of Veigar players I've heard from, this is the primary usage early in lane especially) or farm AP. Theoretically, new Veigar *can* do both, so he can still stack AP *while* harassing the enemy, not *instead* of.
2. Old Veigar would never be able to last hit every single minion in a wave, especially early, simply because of the cooldown and mana cost (it isn't Nasus Q. Heck, it's very difficult if not impossible for Nasus last hit every single minion with Q because of the early cooldown and the fact that your minions will kill their minions). It isn't that there are more minions for him to farm with Q, it's just that he is more able to efficiently farm the existing minions with his Q.

This is also the given justification for the nerf on his ultimate ratio, because according to some of the internal tests they ran, since it was easier for Veigar to stack AP, his ult would be doing even more damage than before even with the reduced ratio because of the extra AP gained; whether this is *actually* the case in the live game and *actually* justified is still debatable, since he *did* lose DFG. At the same time, DFG's removal *was* intended to make mages less bursty, so I think it's a mistake to think that compensatory buffs to any champion will give them back the burst they had with DFG.

I don't think I need to give my opinion on his current state since the current statistics seem to speak for themselves. He's going to receive some buffs in the upcoming patches, and I assume people are still getting a feel for him as a whole; I think once people get used to using his new Q, and assuming the upcoming buffs do enough to help him, he'll be pretty powerful.
